item.title: Sinosphere Blog: With Land Scarce, Chinese School Builds Rooftop Track
item.description: The running track atop the school building provides enough play and exercise space for 1,600 students at a time, the school’s principal told Chinese radio.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: In Interviews, 3 Americans Held in North Korea Plead for U.S. Help
item.description: The three were interviewed by CNN and The Associated Press, and the choreography of the interviews suggested that North Korea wanted to use the prisoners as bargaining leverage.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: U.S. Troops Take Action On Militants In Somalia
item.description: Officials would not say where the operation, against a “senior operative” in the Shabab, took place or give other details.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: World Briefing: Israel: U.N. Chief Criticizes Seizing of West Bank Land
item.description: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon of the United Nations added his voice on Monday to the criticism of Israel over its seizing of nearly 1,000 acres of West Bank land in a Jewish settlement bloc near Bethlehem.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Lesotho: Regional Body Aims to Help Restore Stability
item.description: The Southern African Development Community said Monday that it would send an envoy and an observer team after military actions over the weekend caused the prime minister to flee.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. and Iran Unlikely Allies in Iraq Battle
item.description: The fight for Amerli appeared to mark the first time American warplanes and militias backed by Iran were working with a common purpose on the battlefield against militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga fighters fire toward positions held by the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria during heavy clashes in Tuz Khurmatu, in northern Iraq, on Sunday.

item.title: World Briefing: France: Death Toll Rises to 8 After Building Collapse
item.description: The death toll in the partial collapse of a four-story apartment building in the Paris suburb of Rosny-sous-Bois rose to eight on Monday after emergency crews pulled the bodies of a man and a woman from the rubble.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Travelers to Cuba Face Stricter Rules on Imports
item.description: Cuba has imposed stronger restrictions on goods being brought into the country by relatives of its citizens, meaning some Americans will not be able to deliver as many gifts to their families as they have in the past.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Militants Add Cluster Bombing to Tactics, Rights Group Says
item.description: Human Rights Watch said there was evidence that the extremist group used the munitions in July and August as it fought in northern Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Life in an English Town Where Abuse of Young Girls Flourished
item.description: As young as 11, girls were being lured into a reign of terror in Rotherham, England, but few prosecutions have resulted.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lucy, now 25, was groomed to be a rape victim starting when she was 12. The attacks, by individuals and groups of men of Pakistani origin, in Rotherham, England, often happened outdoors, including an alley, and near the city’s war memorial.

item.title: Pakistani Protesters Ransack State Television Headquarters
item.description: After storming the Pakistan Television building and cutting transmission cables in the newsrooms, antigovernment demonstrators yielded to the military.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters beat a riot policeman on Monday after violence erupted over the weekend in Islamabad, leaving at least three dead and hundreds hurt.

item.title: Memo From Mexico City: Billboard Drives Home Extent of Corruption as Schools Suffer
item.description: In Mexico, which despite a healthy education budget has dilapidated schools, a billboard shows how much money goes to no-show teachers who collect pay without working.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ángel Ramirez, 10, and his brother Luis, 8, outside their school last week in Mexico City.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Foreign Forces in League With Hong Kong’s Democrats Include Gandhi, King, Jesus
item.description: Hong Kong citizens pushing for more democracy are indeed, as People’s Daily, the Chinese Communist Party newspaper, said, colluding “with external forces.” At the top of the list of foreigners influencing the movement: Gandhi, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Jesus Christ.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Demonstrators against Beijing's restrictions on elections for Hong Kong's chief executive gathered Sunday evening near the territory's government complex.

item.title: Tarnishing a Reputation as Storied Warriors
item.description: The Kurdish pesh merga collapse left tens of thousands of defenseless residents in ISIS’ path, further calling into question fundamental assumptions about Iraq’s security.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kurdish pesh merga troops in northern Iraq. The pesh merga collapse last month left tens of thousands of defenseless residents in the path of ISIS militants.

item.title: Decaying Guantánamo Defies Closing Plans
item.description: More than 12 years after the Bush administration first sent detainees to the prison in Cuba, tensions are mounting over whether President Obama can close it before leaving office.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: At the prison in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, last month, two detainees in an outdoor recreation area held a conversation while separated by multiple fences.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: German Broadcaster Is Urged to Speak for Press Freedom in China
item.description: In an open letter, Su Yutong, a Chinese journalist who was fired from a German public broadcaster last month after a debate over the Tiananmen Square massacre, called on the broadcaster’s director general to speak out for press freedom while in China.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Benjamin Kilb for The New York Times
item.media:description: Su Yutong in front of the headquarters of Deutsche Welle in Bonn.

item.title: Germany to Arm Kurds Battling ISIS
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel and top ministers decided Sunday to deliver thousands of machine guns, as well as antitank missiles and armored vehicles to Kurdish forces battling ISIS in northern Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Libyan Militias Seize Control of Capital as Chaos Rises
item.description: A new stage in a power struggle has resulted in rival centers of government, one in Tripoli, and the other in Tobruk.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: U.N. to Send Team to Iraq for Inquiry on ISIS Acts
item.description: The council adopted a resolution without a vote, calling for a team to be sent to Iraq to look into killings and other atrocities.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Salvatore Di Nolfi/KEYSTONE, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Leila Zerrougui, the U.N. special representative of the secretary-general for children and armed conflict, said ISIS is using children as suicide bombers.

item.title: NATO Weighs Rapid Response Force for Eastern Europe
item.description: NATO leaders are expected to respond to increased Russian intervention in Ukraine by establishing a force capable of deploying quickly to Eastern Europe.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The police secured the area outside Cardiff Castle on Monday in preparation for a NATO summit meeting in Wales this week.

item.title: British Leader’s Plan Targets Jihadists’ Passports
item.description: In announcing new police powers, Prime Minister David Cameron was trying to show toughness in the face of young British Muslims’ going off to fight in Syria and Iraq,
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, center, proposed new legislation on Monday that would give the police the power to seize the passports of Britons suspected of traveling to fight with militant groups.

item.title: World Briefing: Geckos on Mission Die Aboard Russian Spacecraft
item.description: Five geckos launched into space for an experiment on sexual reproduction in near-zero gravity were found dead after their spacecraft returned to earth, the Russian space agency said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: As Ukraine Talks Resume, Putin and Poroshenko Trade Barbs
item.description: Mediators held talks on the Ukrainian conflict on Monday, even as President Vladimir V. Putin accused Kiev of seeking to avoid autonomy for southeastern Ukraine.
item.category: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: President Petro O. Poroshenko of Ukraine at a news conference in Brussels on Friday. On Monday, he accused Russia of “direct and open aggression'' against Ukraine.

item.title: Parents Who Left Britain With Ill Son Fight Order to Return
item.description: The parents of Ashya King, 5, who has a brain tumor, attended an extradition hearing in Spain, where they had taken their son after leaving a British hospital against doctors’ orders.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: Ashya King, 5, who has cancer, was taken to Spain from Britain by his parents, who are fund-raising for alternative treatment.

item.title: News Analysis: Democracy Backers in Hong Kong Face Tough Choices
item.description: Students and organizers planned strikes, legal obstruction and a sit-in after the national legislature placed strict limits on how the city may pick its next leader.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Demonstrators supporting a pro-Democracy agenda in Hong Kong disrupted a speech Monday.
